## Operationalization of the social dimension of the doughnut

| **Dimension** | **Indicators Used for Measurement** |
|---------------|-------------------------------------|
| **Food** | 1. Population undernourished<br>2. Population with moderate to severe food insecurity |
| **Health** | 1. Population living in countries with under-5 mortality rate exceeding 25 per 1,000 live births<br>2. Population living in countries without high coverage of essential health services (Universal Health Coverage Index score less than 60 out of 100) |
| **Education** | 1. Adult population (aged 15+ years) who are illiterate<br>2. Young adult population (aged 21-23 years) with incomplete upper secondary education |
| **Income and work** | 1. Population living below the societal poverty line (set at half their country's median household income or at least $15 a day)<br>2. Population of young people (aged 15-24 years) not in employment, education or training (NEET) |
| **Water and sanitation** | 1. Population lacking access to safely managed drinking water<br>2. Population lacking access to safely managed sanitation |
| **Energy** | 1. Population lacking access to electricity<br>2. Population lacking access to clean fuels and technologies for cooking, heating and lighting |
| **Connectivity** | 1. Urban population lacking convenient access to public transport<br>2. Population not accessing the internet |
| **Housing** | 1. Urban population living in slums or informal settlements |
| **Equality** | 1. Population-weighted score on the Gender Inequality Index (global gap between women and men in reproductive health, empowerment and employment)<br>2. Racial inequality (no global indicator currently available) |
| **Social cohesion** | 1. Population stating that they are without someone to count on in times of trouble<br>2. Population living in countries with a Palma ratio of 2 or more (income share of richest 10% relative to poorest 40%) |
| **Political voice** | 1. Population living in countries governed by an autocratic regime |
| **Peace and justice** | 1. Population stating that they perceive widespread corruption in government and business<br>2. Population living in countries with a homicide rate of 5 or more per 100,000 |


Time-series data for the period 2000-2022 is available through the supplementary data of @fanning2025.
:::

## üìö Mandatory Reading

**Read before the lecture:**

- Very concise [video](https://youtu.be/kxQeb2PDz9M?feature=shared) by Kate Raworth introducing the ide of doughnut economics
- Fanning and Raworth [-@fanning2025]
  - A clear and recent introduction to the doughnut approach; I suggest to read it after watching the short video
- Hickel[-@hickel2020a]
  - Concise introduction to what is meant by 'degrowth' (for a crititical view, see further readings)


## üèÜ Further Readings


- Anguelovski and Mart√≠nez-Alier [-@anguelovski2014]
  - Nice introduction to the "environmentalism of the poor", clearly outlining the bidirectional relationship between well-being and environmental protection.
- Trainer [-@trainer2021]
  - A response to the Hickel [-@hickel2020a] reading, illustrating the heterogeneity of the degrowth movement.
- Schmelzer [-@schmelzer2023]
  -  Clearly explains the distinction between growth critiques and GDP critiques.
- Anvaari (2025): [The Doughnut and the Divide](https://developingeconomics.org/2025/08/05/the-doughnut-and-the-divide-can-norway-confront-its-imperial-mode-of-living/)
  - A critical comment on the doughnut concept, written from a decolonial Marxist perspective.
- Richardson et al. [-@richardson2023]
  - Description of the planetary boundary concept and its quantification; example for perspective of earth system sciences.
  
**An important controversy about degrowth:**

- Hickel and Kallis [-@hickel2020]
  - The original argument about the infeasibility of continued growth because of limits to decoupling.
- Warlenius [-@warlenius2023]
  - A critical comment that quantifies how much degrowth would be necessary to meet climate goals if there was the limit of decoupling described by degrowth scholars.
- Jackson et al. [-@jackson2024] and Warlenius [-@warlenius2025]
  - Two rejoinders to the previous two articles, each defending their respective position.
